The safest sign of regime change is when they start to attack the statues .
The Americans appreciate this as well as any other - hence the carefully staged fall of Saddam Hussein in Firdos Square in Baghdad in 2003 .

Stephen Miller , one of the key ideologists of the Trump regime , certainly knew what he did when he took a symbolic axe in a heated dispute with Jim Acosta of CNN on the President ’ s proposals to drastically restrict legal immigration to the Statue of Liberty .
To remain fair , Miller did not attack the statue itself .
A horde of boat owners and liberty imitators would have liked him if he had done so .
But he attacked their meaning , and especially the importance attributed to it when the famous poem of Emma Lazarus was added to its base in 1903 , 17 years after the completion of the monument .
When Miller Acosta insulted : " I do not want to go into a complete thing about history here , but the statue of liberty is ... a symbol of American freedom that illuminates the world .
The poem you refer to , which was added later and is not part of the original statue of freedom . '
Miller is factually right , but as he himself put it , it is not really about history .

It is about contemporary resonance to the shattering words of Lazarus , the only one in which a state not only invites any old immigrants , but the poorest of the poor : ' Your murders , your poor , / your afflicted masses , who want to breathe freely , / the miserable waste of your rich coasts ' .
There was never a time when the ' miserable waste ' on our screens was better to see .
Miller did not engage in literary criticism - he made it clear that these people are not welcome in Trump ’ s US .
This conflict because of the importance of a statue is part of a broader political and cultural debate : it is indeed a conflict about America 's importance .
Lazarus - and her friends who campaigned to place their words on the ground after their death - knew very well that they did a highly political act .
The sculpture should show the links between French and American Republicanism by representing the female embodiment of freedom in a depleted classical picture .
Lazarus changed this meaning : in her poem , the female figure is no longer abstract - she has received a voice .
And she gives herself a very different name : Mother of the exiles .
The combination of the poem with the image is a brilliant feminist coup and a devastating attack on American nativism .
And just as Lazarus changed the meaning of the statue , people on the right wanted to change it back for a long time .

The great script Rush Limbaugh , a kind of John the Baptist for Trump ’ s coming , argued in 2010 that the Statue of Freedom is not inviting anyone , but rather an early neo-conservative that brings the American flame to the surrounded world : “ Lady Liberty is moving forward .

The torch should not illuminate the way to the United States . '

The importance of the statue is absolutely a matter of the position of perception .
The great imaginative act of Lazarus was to see it as seen by the exhausted , miserable but hopeful people after long and often terrible journeys on the decks of ships .
In the truest sense , it is a question of seeing the world from the perspective of people who seek refuge and an opportunity to improve their . the , , , , or , , . , , , ,

In its wooden house in Enarotali , the capital of the Paniai Regency in the troubled Indonesian province of Papua , the housewife normally put a sweet potato - locally called " nota " - directly into the fireplace .

Degei sits on the mud floor - she has no furniture - where she also carries out her daily work , for example to wash clothes with bleak water from the nearby swamp .
